title: Ahmadou Ahidjo
summary: Ahmadou Babatoura Ahidjo (24 August 1924 – 30 November 1989)[1] was a Cameroonian politician who was the first President of Cameroon, holding the office from 1960 until 1982.[2][3] Ahidjo played a major role in Cameroon's independence from France as well as reuniting the French and English-speaking parts of the country.[4] During Ahidjo's time in office, he established a centralized political system. Ahidjo established a single-party state under the Cameroon National Union (CNU) in 1966. In 1972, Ahidjo abolished the federation in favor of a unitary state.[5]
